Supersonic-idiotic-disconnected-brain-infected-overloaded-candy-coated-scum-sucking-dufus. Ever have a really long insult that you used to yell out at school? The above was ours in grade 6 (age 11?). The kid who yelled it the loudest and got it out the first won the battle. Sometimes I feel like yelling it out again, just because someone is ticking me off, but they're not really important enough to take seriously. So, wouldn't it be nice to show them their place with a well timed, well rhymed dis? Isn't that what a lot of rap is about? "A tisket a tasket/ I'll go tit for tat with/ anybody talking this shit that shit/..." Slim Shady knows what it's all about. Nothing makes me feel like letting loose with an over the top insult string like the minor administrative duties of life. Putting phone accounts on hold. Buying travel insurance. Filling out application forms. Checking to make sure you have everything before you leave the house for work only to discover you can't find your keys to lock the door. That kind of crap makes me loopy. Kind of ironic that I've been the height of administrative management this past year as an office manager. I guess that I'm okay with that kind of administration because I feel like it's actually important. If I don't show up for work, people notice. I lose my keys and I don't even notice. Did you know that a one month Eurail pass costs around $1000? I know that travelling is expensive, and yet I am consistently surprised by the amount of money that is gushing through my bank accounts. It's like a river in full spate, large volumes flow in and eddy around for a moment only to disapear into winding, neverending tributaries of people with their hands out. I'm riding a bittersweet high right now - saying permanent goodbye to all my friends is really difficult. Ususally I approach the situation with a nonchalance that I don't feel, but adopt due to fear of turning into a total blubbering, leaking, sap. At the same time, I feel like my life is waiting for me around the corner, all sorts of new friends, challenges, experiences... the whole rest of my life... it's peeking around the corner of the house - like someone who's about to make the dash to safety, but doesn't want to get caught out in their game of hide and go seek. My life is about to dash home and yell "ALL-y All-y HOME FREE!!!!" with straining vocal cords and furious joy at declaring safety without being subject to the hunt. I was completing a transaction at work today, with an elderly lady. The way she asked me to tally up her account would have put me short 58 cents. I tried to explain to her why it wouldn't work, as I would be out money, and then my petty cash wouldn't balance, and then I would have to explain it to my boss, and then she would have to alert head office to the problem, and then head office would have to adjust.... nevermind. Anyway, I was trying to explain the consequences of this faulty transaction, and why I could not do it. The elderly Babe must have been frustrated because in the middle of sentence she interrupts me and says, "Oh, you're just trying to tip yourself!" in a very irate tone. I was stilled. Are you kidding?! 58 cents. fifty-freakin'-eight-cents. That's almost a half a gummi bear at the corner store. She's right, 58 cents could go a long way: GIVE IT HERE! I can't wait to get old and be able to say all sorts of bitter, vile, venemous, accusatory things because I'm wrinkly and my dentures are loose.

Mother Nature screwed up. She makes us humans pretty efficient. We take in food, we get rid of waste... it all doesn't take very much time. So why, oh why, must I got through FIVE days of inconvenience every month? Why can't this process be as efficient as every other process in my body? Why must it take five days to get rid of not very much? Where is the efficiency in that? Can someone (preferrably someone who isn't queasy) explain it to me please? I've just noticed that all my entries are like special gourmet dishes. They are served " a la minute" cooked and prepared, right there, on the spot and served still sizzling from my little typing fingers. There's nothing even remotely timeless about them. It's all in the NOW. I guess 'cause now is the best time. You can never tell what is going to be coming, and then is already gone. I suppose it eliminates any type of preparation, thinking and revising, which could be good - as it keeps me honest, but it could be bad - there are things that maybe should be trimmed, tweaked, twiddled, before they're posted. Meh! Ever had an 80 yr. old woman pat your ass? It's an interesting experience. All you feel is bony hand. It's cheeky and weird at the same time, because you just know that the sweet little granny is thinking back to the time when she was 23 and her ass made men cry and bite their knuckles. Now her ass is covered with some labelled "Serenity" adult "incontinence" pad. How's that for sexy? I can still understand the crying part.

In which our intrepid traveller is preparing for a European trek with her younger (but much bigger) brother. Have been to England every year of my life, so that's where we are going to start. After that: Spain, France, Italy... Switzerland... who knows?? I am borrowing my Dad's massive trekking backpack, which happens to be red. I can't get enough of Canadian flags - I want to sew them on everything I own. Our flights are quite expensive, but that's OKAY! I want to get a tattoo of a Canadian leaf on my body somewhere. I already have a little design on my lower back - I'm not sure how I can incorporate more graffiti with it... any suggestions? Not sure wether I want to put myself through more pain either. And my mother..."Dahling, please don't do it! It's soooooo common." She's British. On the good side of having the flu and feeling nauseous at the smell of food: I've lost ten pounds. Although people are starting to comment that I look a little peaked. A little of column "A" a little of column "B". I'm feeling far too normal today. My muse has deserted me. Mundanity is wreaking havoc on the slightest creative impulses. It's to be expected. No drama for a while will be a good thing.

Just as I was thinking I`m a smarty-pants when it comes to languages... Here I am, in Japan and I haven`t a hope in hell. I can`t even try and sound out words, because the alphabet is so illegible to me. I can`t even get money out of a bank machine by myself because I don`t know what the buttons mean. I am entirely dependant on my hostess. I don`t like being dependant... I am an independant person by nature. I also have a personality type that feeds off information and now I am lost at sea. I cannot read signs, street names, menus, anything. ARGH. Sayonara.

Good heavens. Back from a 5 week trip backpacking around Europe. Leave to go to Japan and Australia within 5 days. Mundanity threatens at home. Was very happy to be back in my own room, with my own bed and no psycho pyromaniacle bunk mates. And now that I've slept here two days I am VERY ready to leave again. I miss meeting people. I miss cheap beer and wine. I miss new sights. How can I miss new sights? I miss discovery. The sense of being raw, new, unprepared for each new city. Just when we got acclimatized to another language, town, landmarks, we left. Time for more raw newness. Japan will be a culture shock. I will be tall. I will be blonde. I will be strange. I will be in a minority. I will eat lots of seafood. I will not find clothes in the shops that fit me. I will be ready for Australia in a couple weeks! Of course, the house is in a turmoil. Mum has sold up and is moving to England. I am now officially, homeless, jobless, car-less, but not quite penniless! It's a very liberating feeling, but also extremely scary. I have nothing to hold me down, but nothing to hold onto either. I could easily floatoff the face of the earth. All my ties that bind have been cut, and now I'm massless. I'm a helium balloon without a string. I'm destined for adventure, and eventual touchdown when I run out of juice. But not for a while. Not for a while. Europe was a good experience. I even had my purse stolen. And it was okay. I was okay. I will be okay. The big bad world might try to get me, but I keep getting up again. Six more weeks travel and I will be back in Toronto, wondering what the hell to do with my life. I think I want to go back to Berlin and teach English. Berlin got into my blood. Berlin gave me a shot of adrenaline, a shot of the fountain of youth, a shot of reassurance. My home will be wherever I choose to make it. I will not be tied to one city for the rest of my life. I CAN feel comfortable in foreign lands. I will learn other languages, and with them, other modes of thought. In Germany no one ever says, "How are you?" unless they really mean it. People there take it seriously. They will really tell you HOW THEY ARE. And if they are strangers then they will think you are being rude and prying. I like that. I like that you don't have to use that meaningless phrase every time you run into someone you know. An elimination of a platitude. Someone once said that people either live their lives out of a centre of fear, or a centre of love. Those who fear try to control. Those who love, accept. I feel like I moved towards love during this trip. You cannot make friends without reaching out. Smile when you make eye contact with someone and see what happens. Being shy will not get you anywhere. Be who you are. Don't pose, pretend or talk shit. Accept. The only valuable thing in life is genuine interactions with other people. REAL living. You will only achieve this if you discard the dross of ego, pretension and fallacy. Ambition is all the greater if you are open about your goals. Ambition becomes something different if you are not entirely self serving.

Got home from the bar last night and as we (my friends and I) were chowing down on our late night fast food binge a commercial came on television advertising lower costing natural gas carriers. The man in the commercial faints and falls backwards when he discovers how much money he's saved on his heating bill. I was petrified. I almost started to cry. Normalacy frightens me so much that I almost started to cry . Dear sweet heaven, I don't want to face the reality of the rest of life. I bloody well refust to accept that version of life. I am determined that somewhere inside me is the strength to live a life less ordinary. The idea of a house, with cable bills and small children and a man who kisses me on the cheek every morning as he goes off to the same job 5 times a week... no thank you. Some other McCookieCutter combo life please.

Sleepless. My inner clock is all messed up – still on Australian time. First priority on arriving back in Canada: recouperate my music collection. Can’t believe how much it matters to me. Am also incredibly eager to see all my friends, catch up, get reconnected. Japan was an experience that made me aware of how I live. Bare shoulders here in Canada are normal, in Japan bare shoulders are tarty. Electronic toilets in Japan are run of the mill (they even have two different kinds of jet water squirts), electronic toilets here are unheard-of. I live a strange life. A semi-charmed life. And now, what do I want to do with it? What job can I do that I will LOVE, that will not feel like work, that will offer a sense of accomplishment but won't leave me poor? I could write blogs for a living, but then, I would be poor. I also have a feeling that I would have to be more careful and artistic about it, rather than just setting down all the inanities in my head. I would also have to spell correctly. Not-so-much. What to do, what to do? Back to school for a bit, back to work for a while, and back to Australia in a couple years. I gotta go back. I gotta: ~learn how to surf ~parasail ~get my scuba diving certification ~go horse back riding ~camp out in the outback ~hike through the rainforest ~pet more Koalas ~get through some of the watering holes ~go canyoning ~white water raft All these things and more, I gotta gotta do! What has everyone else done? What would you do? You're homeless, jobless but not hopeless. Employable, but unsure as to which vocation to follow. Where do I start? I need money to go to school to see if I want to do certain things that would lead to a career. To get money to go to school I need a job. How do I get a job in a career that I might want to get into but still have to go to school for? Therein lies the quandry. I can't remember who said it, but someone did, "There is inspiration in everything. If you don't see it, look harder." I say a television show on redecorating - their inspiration for a new master bedroom? Tiffany's. As in the jewellery store. As in Turquoise and white ribbons. Interesting. Inspiration is everywhere. Why can't I find it sometimes? My muse must be fickle. Either that or I'm just some part time job that she's filling in time for some extra cash, or brownie points, or however the Muse Payment System works. Apparently there are 80,000 books published per year in the USA. Maybe my muse is too busy helping the real writers in their literary works. What happens if you feel creative, you know it in your bones and you try to BE creative and live a creative life and you can't? What happens then? Are you just trying too hard? Should you just let creativity happen around you, or should you continue to work at it? Continue to look for inspiration in everything. Inspiration in the way the furnace rattles when it turns on? Inspiration in the sign above my head that says "Katanga spoken here"?! Inspiration in the early light over a suburb of Toronto? Inspiration in looking for inspiration. At least frustration gives me something to write about. I am given subject matter by my complete lack of any proper subject matter. I've been most of the way around the world, 11 countries in one year and I don't really have much to say about it. I hold my experiences to myself, refusing to believe that anyone really wants to hear that the Swiss graveyards are a riot of colourful flowers, and that Australia feels like it's in the middle of nowhere, when it's not really. Perhaps I dread trying to explain my feeling because I don't analyze them. To expound on them, I would have to monitor what I am thinking and why, and then try and express it in an interesting manner that other people would actually want to hear. Hmmmmmm. Do other people really want to hear that?! Do they?

And christmas has come and gone and new years is almost here and now what? I refuse to make resolutions, I'm full of them already and they are not going according to plan. What ever does go according to plan? An inventory of relationships One uncle in love: age 42 and skipping around like a 12 year old with a new toy. Irritatingly happy and motivated. Rose coloured glasses are distorting his world and I have to put up with it. One father breaking up with his girlfriend: irritatingly moody and unpleasant. Cynical. Smokes more and smiles less. Future so dark he has to wear a miner's light to see one day ahead of himself. Me: in the middle of relationship weirdness. One good friend who is more than that, but I don't want to commit. One email companion who is really nothing, yet - but promising. Lots of people from the past popping up during the holiday season - disconcerting. No one likes to be reminded of their mistakes. One mother in England missing her dining room table - the shipping company has sent out an urgent search for it. Description: Mahogany, old, recently refinished, art nouveau legs and feet that appear to melt into the floor. If you've seen it, please email me, I'm tired of calling the shipping company for status updates. One grandmother who can do the crossword in the Toronto Star in about 10 minutes, EVERY morning. 40 new friends at work - am finally getting settled and accepted. Must quit soon! 3 close friends I miss dearly - feel free to move to Toronto, or at least get your drivers' liscenses so that you can come visit me! 1 malfunctioning cell phone, due possibly to the lapse in my payments to Bell over the past three months. HATE bell, but understand why they don't want me to rack up anymore money owing. HATE THEM. 1 dial up internet connection - this is frustrating. It's killing me. Soon to change. 3 stereo systems: YES! One old cat: arthritis makes her joints pop as she walks. Sounds like rice krispies. Kinda funny actually. 16 rolls of film documenting 3 months of travelling. Feel like I never left at all. One computer. Two rooms of storage full of furniture, books and clothes. Soon to be empty. One new landlord. Is he ever in for a surprise! Zero cars. Ouch. 35 over due bills. Kidding. 3 over due bills. For real. One pair of new red boots. Made for walking, provided they are weatherproofed and there is no snow or ice around. Correction: One pair of new red boots. Made for sitting and looking good in. The end!

Email from Japan: "You are bord your job,aren't you? I think you'll change your job.Because you are very smart.I think there is nice occupation agreeable to your tartes." I think my tartes are outnumbered.

Conversation overheard between Dad and Grandma... Grandma says," Betty Richmond is looking really good! They cauterized something and it worked wonders." Wow, can't wait to be old. In the search for a job with meaning... something that I don't need a doctorate for. Champion television watcher, chief straying fork, ultimate web surfer? Working full time in retail is souless, painful and stifling. Even thinking about what I have to do for 8 hours a day cripples any sense of hope.
soon to have my very own apartment. everyone I ever met travelling is welcome to drop by!

Interesting old lady on the bus. Spent half and hour yelling, "85th division, 95th division, 105th division! All involved in crimes against my family! 45th division, they're the worst! It's all dirty garbage! You can like it, or lump it. The whole police force! The 35th division, oh yes, that goes all the way back to the 80's. All involved in crimes against my family. Dirty garbage. They're killling us with the windows DOWN!" Weird eh? Interesting young man on the bus. My water bottle fell over and he actually got up and set it upright for me. And then he held the door open for me at the bus station. And then I ran off to catch my transfer. I wonder who he was? I wonder if other people do this? I've decided I like taking the bus. It might be a long trip every morning and night, but I either get some good reading, or some interesting stories to tell. Interesting indeed...

Today is a day that makes all the cabin fever Canadians go slightly insane. If I was in my home town right now, I could drive down certain streets and see the front lawns of certain houses decorated with couches, University students and beer-a-mids. Today is the kind of day that you step outside and think, "Why wasn't I up with the birds to enjoy this?" Today is the kind of day that the dirty snow melts and there are fresh streams running down all the pavements and the soggy brown grass underneath the snow starts to show. Today is the kind of day when there are 1/2 hr. line ups at the car wash, to get all the salt, muck and winter slime off a car that will soon sparkle almost as much as the sun does. Today is the kind of day that I hear birdsong and realize how long it's been since I heard it last. Today is the kind of day that even though you are inside, you can just tell that it's blissfull outside. Today is the kind of day that you open all the windows of the house, because although it's not quite warm yet, the air is certainly fresh, and you can smell a preview of summer in the breeze. Today is the kind of day when going for a long, random walk is the best thing to do. Today is the kind of day that makes people happy.
The dream of finding love is the only thing that keeps me awake. -Me

Life is so so so crazy. Or should I say, "woo woo"? I'm dating now. I met a guy at a bar a couple weeks ago (I know, the bar scene has typically horrific results). Gave out my phone number for the first time ever. He calls me a week later, after I've been checking my call display like a child waiting for christmas. We set up a date. Date starts out great, even though he's two hours late. We have dinner and "same page" conversation. He holds my hand. I get all embarrassed but like it. We go to one of his friends' house. We head to the same bar where we met. Things are already going downhill. He's had about 9 drinks and then KABLAM!! he turns into "Mr Fucknuts." 3 hours later I am driving his stupid FUCKING loaded ASS home in his standard car. I don't know how to drive standard. We stop at his house and he says, "I won't kiss you until it means something, but we can have sex!" I laugh. But wait, he's serious. "C'mon, just let me put it in you." AND "you should get on the pill soon." "But I don't want to get on the pill." "That's okay, I don't need to come inside you. I bet I could unload at least four shots our first time." I have known him for 7 hours. He calls me the next day to apologize. At 3am. Drunk. I am calm and nice. Always too nice. I explain to him why I don't want to see him. He says he understands and we hang up. He calls me later to make really sure that I can't forgive him for being a total FUCKHEAD. This time it's 3:30 am. Again I am nice, again I tell him that I never want to see him. Finally he says that he will never call me, but if I ever feel like I can forgive, then he would really like to have another date. He promises that he won't get drunk this time. After all, "out of all the of the girls I'm dating, I like you the best."

Weird sleeping patterns recently. Trippy dreams too. Last weekend I was dining at Buckingham Palace - in one of those great halls all embossed with gold leaf and the walls covered in a uneven layer of family portraiture, done in heavy oils. I was sandwiched between my lunch companions, but can't remember who they were. I don't remember that the Queen was there either, but she's not really that important. True to my sensualist nature, I do remember the dessert. It was a chocolate cup cake - in the shape of flower pot bread. Into the bottom of this cup cake, they had stuffed a small egg shape mound of very cold mint-chocolate ice cream. I was thinking: I must remember this! I can make it myself! It was cold and delicious. As for last night's dream... This must be the first time that I have fallen in love while asleep. He's large - in all senses - the build of the incredible hulk. But he's a hulk who hasn't worked out for a while, so all the popping veins and chiselled muscles have softened - making him less frightening. He is 42 (!! - note, I'm 24) and has a brush cut of blonde/grey hair, that he used to wear longer in a fashionable type bowl cut. He is an athlete of some sort, or vaguely associated with the Navy seals. We went to a funeral where everyone was dressed in outdoor activity clothing. Someone portaged the corpse resting in a small aluminium boat down to the river, where they launched it into the rapids with little ceremony. All the funeral guests were half concealed among the gold and red changing autumn trees. After the boat launch, they all melted away - like spies eager to disappear. Back to the man I was in love with... we had a shower together in a cavernous tiled blue/grey room that was completely featureless except for the faucet and shower head protruding from one wall. I can feel the warm deliciousness of the water soaking my hair as we clung together under the nozzle. My largest bath sheet barely met over his shoulders. I woke up in the morning (in my dream) and he was sitting on the floor beside the bed, his eyes level with my pillow, watching me sleep. I'm bashful and just look at him in contemplation. He says, " Would you believe me if I told you that I hadn't been this happy in years?" and I can't stop myself from smiling, but hid my face in my pillow and grin and grin and grin. His blue eyes sparkle with welcome and good humour as he climbs back into bed with me and strokes my bare arm. I am in love. But he has skin cancer. I keep thinking about how healthy he looks, but how so vital a man will have to be cared for as his cancer progresses. I look forward to nurturing and maintaining that happy spark in his eyes. Cancer is nothing. It doesn't stand a chance. So I wake up, for real - full of love. In love. And the feeling stays with me for most of the day. Now, whenever I need it, I can think about how I felt and remember how it is to have someone like that in your life. Sweet bliss.
Mmmmmmmmm and that George Stromboloupoulous *crush* thingy has evaporated. Probably 'cause I met the Bay St. version, in real life. Real is definitely better than TV.

I have now started my proper job and this is my first week on my own. I hardly need to say how happy I am to be sitting behind a desk, looking at a computer screen and feeling my eyeballs turn dry and square. So much less exquisitly painful than standing in a shop, trying to get people to buy clothes that they don’t need and won’t (please don’t!) wear. I miss the music and the stimulation of the store. I don’t miss the rude imbeciles, bellowing children and having to refold t-shirts until my arms give out. I loathed my previous job, and now, I’m just a happy little bunny. On my way to work I get to go through one of the scarier neighbourhoods in Toronto. Lots of drugs, lots of homeless people. The homeless provide me with a sense of perspective, and a sense of humour. Today I watched from out of the streetcar as a man raked his fingers through his woman’s hair and then carefully braided it down the centre of her back. When he was done, they returned to their seats... she on a plastic milk carton, he on the rancid sleeping bag. It was touching and terribly sad. They were so caring towards each other, but their lifestyle looks so hopeless. I often wonder why the wanderers collect the strange junk that they cling to. Bicycles, I understand... but office furniture? What possible use can a rolling chair be to anyone without a room to put it in? I’ll tell you what use it can be. Aparently, they make good pillows. The guy had the chair laying on the grass in the park, the arms facing into the sky. The backrest was the resting place for his head. And VOILA! A 40 pound, solid construction, plastic, foam and upholstery pillow. Or maybe he was just lying on it like that so no one would steal it? So far I’ve seen: • Three fights - one involving a “Matrix” type of leap into the air and flying, flailing kicking. • A man reach out and grab a skinny crackwhore type girl and try and put his hand down her pants. • A man get on the streetcar with bright turquoise surgical gloves on, careful to make sure his skin touches nothing. His jeans though, are completely putrid, covered in slime, dirt and muck. He can’t be that concerned about personal hygine. Oh yeah, he followed me to work too. Creepy.

I've decided that I can't relate to people who get the blues. Nor do I understand the "mean reds", nor even the deep blacks. No, I get something altogether less colourful. I get the "slows". Moving fast - not an option. Moving at all - not an option. Thinking clearly - not an option. Thinking at all - not an option. When I'm feeling crappy I seem to live my life in a suspension of maple syrup and molasses. My thoughts go 'round and 'round, swirling in the most decadent, meandering way... My body feels bloated, so far removed from the ballerina I dream at night. Motivation disapears. Everything is too damn much effort. Even complaining. The best thing to do when I have the slows, is to go to bed. Sleep it off. Sleep until I can't sleep anymore and I'm so full of nervous energy that I just have to DO something... and then that something usually gets rid of the slows.

Standing watching the subway train pull into the station and I think how easy it would be to just step in front of it. Only my small, quick firing synapses keep me from moving those perilous two feet to death. So easy to die... So easy to just let go of the caring and step out into the void, pulling my screaming mind after me. Where would the sweet release take me? My new adventure would begin, leaving mourners and confusion. I am not unhappy. I just have a strong case of cat-killing curiosity. What would it FEEL like, not to feel anymore. Why does my brain hold me back from the edge so imperatively. Why is it so important that I stay safe and sound on the platform? Would I feel the train making contact, or would I just go black. I could easily trip, fall, stumble, get pushed. The weapons of destruction are all around us. You can kill someone with rolled up newspaper. The nuclear bomb is scary, the guy who thinks up how to kill someone with any given object, that's terrifying. Death stalks us from the minute we are born. I will die anyway, why not go at a time of my own choosing. Why not go in an adventurous way, rather than that every hoped-for "in the sleep" senario. Maybe death is just the begining and this, this little bit of time is my purgatory. I must say, I don't have many issues with this kind of limbo life. I'm learning, I live passionately, sumptuous in my relaxtion, electric in my action. But where would that step off the platform take me? Into what realm, dimesion, conciousness would I emerge? Is there anything to emerge into at all? Ah yes, the slippery afterlife... bright lights and melifluous voices? Chared, burning agony? Vacuum? Un-being? Release into the cosmos? Carebear lifestyle? Like I said, cat-killing curiosity.

What did we do?!" and then, after a diginified pause you shriek, "I C an't R emember A F ucking T hing!" and now you have gained admission to one of the most respected, prestigious, far-reaching and powerful organiztion in the world. We have literaly millions of honorary members... including the person who coined the term "coyote ugly" and all those guys in movies who wake up next to creepy strange women. Now there are rules to belonging. Hommage must be made to the alcohol gods at least twice a month, at worst, or 5 times a week (at best). A pilgrimage must be made. Visiting either a brewery, a winery, or the place where they make rubbing alcohol is mandatory. You are expected to enter these hallowed grounds in a smiling, decorus manner and not leave until you have been bodily ejected for puking either: on the tour guide, on the grape vines, into a barrel containing fermenting yeast or such like, all over the rest of the tour group. Projectile vomiting is not necessary, but recommended. Once you have returned to your hotel/hostel/house/appartment/condo/hole in the ground you must loudly proclaim our name, "I can't remember a fucking thing!" At this point you should be quizzed by a friend as to where you wen't, who you were with and why you got kicked out. Email from my ex-step brother (read:brother) in England. He stayed with my Mum for the first couple days. Funny to hear how about the New Forest from someone who's never been there before. I'm accustomed to the wandering livestock now... although it's still somewhat frightening to suddenly come across eight very large highland cattle in the middle of a forest trail. (1) England I spent my first three days in england with my ex step sister's real mom, which makes her my... well, um...god only knows. At least it's good to know that the simon family circus stretches across continents. She lives in the south of england in a region known as the New Forest, which since it's nearly 1100 years old, might be a bit misleading. But, having just arrived, I thought it best to keep that to myself. The gig here is that it's William the Conquerer's old personal hunting ground. As a result, the ponies, donkeys and cattle (people hunt these things?) run free and have developed a keen sense of how to stand squarely in front of cars. Darwinism at work I guess. (2) Stansted Airport Off to sweden. Stansted airport is situated somewhere and hour or so north east of London... I say somewhere because it's literally in the middle of nowhere. No hotels, restaurants or bars. Nada. Fortunately, they have developed this extensive bus and train system there. It works something like this: first flights of the morning leave at 6.10, next wave of flights leave at 6.30 (like mine). The first buses of the morning arrive about 6.50. Excellent. The result? Spending a night at Stansted airport! So I arrived around 11pm thinking I'd be one of a couple of travellers in such a predicament, only to discover that about 300 travellers had the same plan. Devastating. And so I became friends with perhaps the most uncomfortable airport chair ever developed. The key, I was told, was to adopt a zen-like attitude to the nearly 8 hours of good times ahead... there is no past. no future. only the now. Live in the now. Yeah, as you might guess, that crap wears off after about 6 minutes. He's still got about two more weeks of travelling, I can't wait to hear what he thinks about Berlin... It was my favorite city in all of Europe.

urlLink 9/11'S LEGACY: UNCERTAINTY "Then I spotted the photo in the middle of the display, which showed one of those heartbreaking sidewalk shrines that popped up all over Lower Manhattan after the World Trade Center fell. A tattered poster of a missing woman, flowers and candles. And I remembered what actually happened that day: 19 angry young men, most of them Saudis, carried out a foul plan they had hatched three years earlier in Hamburg, and murdered as many thousands of Americans as they possibly could. Every once in a while, you realize you've edited your memories, put them in little boxes, so you can get on with your life. Most people have built a little wall in their minds between their knowledge of Sept. 11 and their memory of it. You can debate defence spending or moan about airport security without really thinking. The searing memory stays in its place, off to the side. Mostly. Not always." I know that there are no more twists and turns that I might miss out on. Let's get our terms straight Before we go throwing around words that have become popular, but who's meanings have been obscured... urlLink Homophobia Why don't people just call each other "poo-poo head" instead of dragging out a mouthful like "homophobic"? It's really on the same level. The "phobic" part of "homophobic" means "frightened of" or "scared by." It implies an irrational, exaggerated fear of something. Note that it does not imply all forms of fear. If I were to the top of the office tower they're building down the street, walk to the edge of the new floor they just poured and look down, my stomach would probably go all swimmy, I would clutch at something, and I would probably be terrified. This is not a phobia. This is my body saying, "What in God's name are you doing so far off the ground, you moron?!?" It's perfectly natural. Mrs. Buster has a fear of heights. She can't climb stairs in a movie theatre if they're the steps-only, open-backed kind. Seeing down just one story makes her freeze up. That's a phobia. So, I am not homophobic, I just don't really understand same sex non-platonic love. I'm certainly not irrationally scared of it.

Thoughts on turning a quarter century... I saw the Disney Peter Pan movie when I was four. I went home and cried, and cried, and cried. I knew, like Peter, that I never wanted to grow up. I mean, highschool students had homework to do (gasp!), University Students had the life sucked out of them, and adults, well - you didn't see any of them enjoying the jungle gym at the park. Nope, definitely had my heart set on staying four, forever. I used to believe that if I jumped high enough off the steps of my back porch I would just continue on up into the sky. If I jumped really really really hard, I would escape the bounds of gravity and I would FLY. That's what I used to wish for before I became aware of money. Now my happiest dreams are the ones where I'm performing Swan Lake, and I hit those 32 fouettes without a stumble. In fact, after the 32 turns, I keep going - my balance is perfect, I can spin forever. I have these dreams a lot. If I found a magical lamp with a genie in it, I would still wish for a lot of money, but I would also wish to be four again. This time, I would jump high enough and I really would fly. And every night I would have my spining dream and grow up, just like that.

I’m going back to the start. "No one said it would be easy/ No one said it would be so hard." - Coldplay I've been pondering the pro's and con's of comments recently and although I value the insight and intelligence of the contributions, I've decided to disable the comments. I started this blog as a catharsis. I wanted to spew whatever was beautiful or horrendous in my head. Now I find I self edit. Now, I wonder what people will think. I wonder if so-and-so will applaud, I wonder if what's-their-name will vilify me. Most comments are supportive, intriguing - provoking. But I feel the need to be selfish. I want to be fearless. I want to say whatever I think. I want to set down how I used to smoke pot. I want to set down how many mistakes I've made. I want to set down those dark corners of my mind that won't talk to anyone. I want to deface or exalt this page, according to my mood. I want to feel truly disconnected from where I am. So, I bid you all adieu and thank you for enriching me. I've appreciated all of your ranting, your cosseting, your mild flirting, your contributions. I feel lucky to know that I did write posts that left people with something to say. But now, you will have to forgive me for making my page my own, again. urlLink So long, and thanks for all the fish.

I was just channel surfing and came across an indie movie. Unusual, they come on later at night. Anyway, the first shot was of a guy and a girl, he, rolling a joint. They're sitting at opposite ends of his bed-on-the-ground. The second shot, they've sprawled out a little, they're smoking. The third shot they've lain down, side by side, hands crossed on their chests, giggling at the ceiling. I wonder how many other people can relate to this? For me, it's like a page out of my memory, shown on television, for anyone who might be curious. I used to have this same ritual with one of my exes. We'd lie there, burbling laughter, feeling warm colours explode in our veins. I gained about 10 pounds from eating too much munchie fast food. We'd either fall asleep together, curled up in a satisfied cocoon, or make slow, lazy love - not quite believing the intensity of the feeling, knowing that it will be impossible to recall in the morning. The relationship ended badly but to this day, I will remember what it felt like to float above the bed and know that someone beside me was sharing the experience. Of course, smoking pot twice a day isn't good for your brain, and I ended up on academic probation for my last year of University. I got tired of making myself stupid and sleepy. I got tired of eating wretched food at 4 a.m. I got tired of coughing, and smelling like sweet, burnt herbs. I got tired of him, and his insistence on using dope for release. I got out of it, and graduated with honours. I got A's for the first time in my University career. But sometimes, it would be nice to be stupid again.

urlLink Philosoraptor He has an answer to the urlLink Du Toit "Wimpification" Essay I’m torn about Kim du Toit’s essay about, as I’ll put it, avoiding his gratuitous crudity, the wimpification of the Western male. I’m inclined to ignore it, since it’s unlikely that anyone who found the essay insightful will listen to anything I have to say about it; but du Toit is full of shit, and that, combined with the apparent popularity of the essay on the right wing of the web makes it hard to ignore. I’m torn about it also because there is, in fact, an important and true point in the essay. I’d put the point this way: we’re in danger of undervaluing virtues like courage and self-reliance that are traditionally thought of as masculine. Now, I’d add—though du Toit might not--that for almost all of human history we’ve done just the reverse, undervaluing virtues like kindness and cooperation that are traditionally thought of as feminine. So I see the problem of wimpification as a relatively minor, relatively recent and eminently correctable phenomenon, a predictable case of the pendulum swinging a bit too far in the other direction as we try to correct a bigger and more long-term problem. But I do agree with du Toit to some extent, and I do think that the threat of wimpification is worth discussing. That’s why it’s too bad that du Toit’s essay is such a piece of crap--the wimpification point gets lost in a torrent of bigotry, falsehoods, and right-wing fantasies. Intelligent, carefully thought out, and sound in reasoning. Two thumbs way up. Not that I'm any authority.

Oh how I love shopping. Or at least, I thought I did. Yesterday, I saw (for the first time) the ugly underbelly of commerce. Gold was 1/2 price at the Hudson's Bay Company. Except a necklace that was worth $80 had been marked up to $300. What a load of shit. My primary peeve about packed malls are the people who stop in the middle of an aisle, look around dazedly and then mosey on again. Goddamit, can't you see that I'm here to do business? Don't just stop dead in front of me. You deserve every jostle you get you wrinkled old bag-with-a-cane. My brother was emmitting those warning signal traits that I have come to associate with immediate need for exodus. Mumbling under his breath, glaring, shoving, accidentally saying, "Fuck you" instead of, "thank you" to the people who were ringing up his gifts. And what's with those families who let their kids play in the fountain? For christ's sake, we're not at "Wild Water World", it's fucking MALL. One lady was even video taping her toddler splashing around. Don't get out much, do we? My shopping trip was still quite successful, I spend more money than I wanted, I bought things that I'm not sure people will like, and I forgot to get the one thing that I actually had planned out. So now, I'm going to have to head downtown tonight after work, and go through it all again. I look forward to it. One thing that did make day brighter than a new penny: Last year at this time I was WORKING in one of these malls. In a women's clothing store called JACOB. I went into the store yesterday to help my brother find things for his girlfriend. I saw a lot of familiar faces, all of whom looked just about miserable. I sent my prayers up to whatever the hell lives in sky, "THANK YOU THANK YOU, I do not work here anymore. I do not work in retail. I will not have to work 12 hours on boxing day. I will not have to deal with the simpletons who didn't like their gifts and want to exchange their blouse for a piece of my soul over the coming weeks." Thanksgiving comes twice a year, for me.

Here's some more good points about urlLink communism and why it doesn't work. urlLink Matt (the darling) has his thinking cap on... Personally I think it is more then greed that is the problem with communism. It is (IMO of course) the lack of competition. Humans thrive on competition. One of the grater ironies of the human condition is that it has the effect of bringing out the best in us and the worst in us. But it does bring out the best in us. Like it or not the drive to be better then the other guy/girl/team/nation/whatever is a serious part of our make-up. Communism takes away any reward for doing a better job then the other guy, so why bother trying? That is why during the reign of the USSR people would literally risk their lives to smuggle Levis into the country. You couldn’t get a quality pair of Russian made jeans because workers got paid the same for a lot of effort as for a little. Levis were worth hundreds of dollars used. Then there is the fact that the ultimate competition, war, is responsible for more technological advancement thru-out our history then any other factor. Capitalism may bring about some of the worst human traits, but it also with out a doubt brings out the best too. And that's why we love urlLink him .

R.E.: "Communism is for robots. Take away possessions, take away all that shit and leave a person with just their animal passions. What are you left with? The need to eat, sleep, have shelter, fuck, and work. Communism covers these basic needs, but doesn't allow a human being to develop further than this. There is no room for the individual. It is for robots. You become a number." Me: But capitalism is just a different kind of number. I'm still just the sum of my bank account, my health card #, my driver's license, my street address, my IP address, my user login... I'm individual in this combination, but I'm still a number. Bureaucracy creates populations as numbers. Communism limits your material possessions, and with that comes the limiting of self expression. I think that communism's main flaw is that of corruption. Those at the top are not participating in the system. There are always the "have" and the "have nots". As long as human greed exists, communism will fail. Both because the leaders are corrupt and because the peons are always left wanting more. I do agree that communism would be great for robots though. If human beings ever learn to be happy when ONLY their basic needs are met, then communism will succeed. The problem (and great blessing) is that we strive for self-actuation, and expression. Expression involves not only free speech, but also the chance to believe in different systems of society, different political parties, and extremist means of expression.

Should this be an actual relationship? urlLink Things he and his girlfriend have argued about. Margret doesn't like to watch films on the TV. No, hold on - let me make sure you've got the inflection here: Margret doesn't like to watch films on the TV. She says she does, but years of bitter experience have proven that what she actually wants is to sit by me while I narrate the entire bleeding film to her. 'Who's she?', 'Why did he get shot?', 'I thought that one was on their side?', 'Is that a bomb' - 'JUST WATCH IT! IN THE NAME OF GOD, JUST WATCH IT!' The hellish mirror-image of this is when she furnishes me, deaf to my pleading, with her commentary. Chair-clawing suspense being assaulted mercilessly from behind by such interjections as, 'Hey! Look! They're the cushions we've got.', 'Isn't she the one who does that tampon advert?' and, on one famous occasion, 'Oh, I've seen this - he gets killed at the end. See if you can spot the difference between these two statements: (a) "Those trousers make your backside look fat." (b) "You're a repellently obese old hag upon whom I am compelled to heap insults and derision - depressingly far removed from the, 'stupid, squeaky, pocket-sized English women,' who make up my vast catalogue of former lovers and to whom I might as well return right now as I hate everything about you." Maybe the acoustics were really bad in the dining room, or something. Ah, the sweet, whispered nothings of love.

I have a bowl It is a pretty bowl, slightly wonky, bold black and white. It is light, about the size of half a basket ball. It has a japanese design inside the rim. The design means "adventure". It wasn't expensive, but it cost enough to be treated gently. I put my bowl in a box. I put my bowl in a box with an address label on it. The address label shows that it wants to be sent to a small cottage on the south coast of England. The address label and the box want to have stamps put on them, so that the pretty bowl can go to England. Instead, the address label has holly leaves drawn on it. The box will be the lucky receipient of the stamps. The man at the post office looks at the (now) pretty box. He knows that there is a pretty bowl inside it. A light, pretty bowl, that wants to go to England. The man at the post-office carefully weighs the pretty box and measures it. The man at the post office types on his little keyboard and says, "$94.80 please." The pretty bowl in the pretty box is sitting on the counter at home, in Toronto, Canada. It does not get to go to England because $94.80 is too much for a bowl adventure. Poor bowl.

I meet up with my older brother downtown for dinner on a friday night. We come upon some of his friends from law school... and thus starts a nonsense night of liquor. At four a.m. I'm at a dive with plywood floors, plywood benches and a rock cover-band singing unnoticed standing on milk crates. The dive sells liters of "ginger ale" for $40. Very potent ginger ale. In fact, ginger ale that tastes suspiciously of rye whiskey. Everyone knows about this. My brother is off dancing to the rock with a pretty blonde. In fact, he's less dancing and more making out. He pauses and after about 30 seconds says, "I'm sorry, maybe I should have told you this earlier, but I have a girlfriend." I am mortified. I go up to his apartment to use the facilities, call a cab and pay the $28 fare to get home. The next day I call my brother and freak on him, "You could've told me he has a girlfriend!" My brother says, "I don't really know that guy... sorry. By the way, what did you say to him?" I told him, " I asked if he was up for a night of cuddles and chats." Mu brother... "You what?!" [My name] that means that you want to have sex!" Me: "No it doesn't... it means exactly what I said. I'm not into one night stands! What are you talking about?!" Brother: "From a guy's point of view, that means you WANT HIM." Christ. I was under the impression that it meant what I thought it meant. Doesn't it?

Other things that you should NEVER try to return: socks, belts, footwear, bras, intimate wear, two year old merchandise, merchadise that you have completely fucked, merchandis covered in your dog's hair/stained/damp for some reason. Ah yes, the "organic" debate. I don't usually buy organic food, because I can't afford it. The idea of all shit that's in everything else is freaky though. urlLink Macleans.ca : "FROZEN ORGANIC beef hamburger patties, $9.78/kg. Grade No. 1 organic onions, $2.26. On-the-vine, hothouse organic tomatoes, $11/kg. Eating a hamburger that doesn't load you down with chemicals, priceless. Well, maybe. Some shoppers would just say pricey. Those organic ingredients -- when compared to the common ones regrettably seasoned with traces of antibiotics, growth hormones and pesticides -- can cost anywhere from 15 to 170 per cent more. But it's come to this, hasn't it? Most Canadians would never accept a two-tiered health-care system, yet that's the direction in which we seem to be heading with our food. Consumers who are at least reasonably well-off can afford the good stuff, while those who are financially strapped make do. As shown by the scares with mad cow disease and tainted farmed salmon, our increasingly industrialized food chain may turn out to be the pitfall that keeps us from what could otherwise be a long, healthy life." Even if we do eat healthily there are still the environmental risks that we come into contact with every day... pollution, radio waves, chemicals... you name it. I can picture a return to the pioneering days - everyone farms their own vegetables, we use horses to get around and pump our own water from the well in the back yard. If we don't start cleaning up our act, we will be reduced to this - without any other options.

I'm pretty sure that someone who actually knows me is reading this blog. They spent almost an hour reading my archives on their first visit, and now they are checking the site almost twice a day. The owners of the cat house have just left Burma Well now, I've just read this myself and Burma sounds kind of horrible, doesn't it? Let me sum it up this way. When you travel where we do, you should expect somewhere around 50% to 70% of your time to be a bit of a hardship. Its what's left over that makes it all worth while. I've always found, the poorer the country, the friendlier the people. Burma is no exception. No where will you find a kinder, more gentle human being than in Burma. Many a day, you'll notice a child staring at you. A tiny grin in the kid's direction will almost always be rewarded with a huge ear to ear smile. If I were to ever take up religion again, I think it will be Buddhism. The temples have a great sense of serenity. I think that the people are a reflection of that. Foreign policy would have you believe that Burma is a dangerous place. I've never felt safer. Bagan is magical. Inle Lake is second to that. The food is a new pleasure with every meal. Back in Thailand now, I dream of Burma. I'm beginning to babble now. I've misplaced my betel nut. Oh, am I ever jealous. I wish I could be there. I'd even settle for Thailand.

I am at work. I am at work, utterly alone. There is no one else here, but me. Did I miss something? Am I supposed to be at home in bed right now? Where are all the naughty little engineers? Have we been awarded an extra day off that I am currently frittering away by actually doing work? Well, I'm not really working, am I? I'm updating my blog. But still. I'd rather be back in bed. Under the duvet. Warm and unconcious. I'm still hung over. I think I deserve an extra day in bed. After the big break up last night. That's right. R.E. and I are going to be friends from here on in. I talked to him about the way he had begun to treat me and it all came tumbling out in some big mess. He's currently depressed. He wants to be with me, but doesn't think it's fair to start a relationship while he's not mentally healthy. I'm agreeing with this. So, we decide to call it quits. I'm actually quite relieved... I don't have to worry anymore, or wonder what's going on in his head, or take him to task for some insensitive comment. He, of course, is completely 'round the bend with sorrow, keeps calling me to cry on the phone, worried about how sad I must be. I'll admit it, I am sad, he is a wonderful guy, but right now the relief at having the situation sorted out outweighs the sadness. At least I've learned one important lesson. A couple of years ago I would have convinced him that it's okay for us to continue how we were, and that by staying with him I could support him in his bad times. I would want to FIX him. But now, I realize that he must fix himself. Then, maybe then, we could have a proper relationship. Hey ho, it's on with life we go.

urlLink John Strain left this comment at urlLink Fear Not . I decided not to be anonymous, because I want the restraints in place. The restraints of which I speak have to do with, would I say this in front of my mother, or would I be embarrassed if ANYONE knew I said this or that. This way I am challenged to communicate more middle of the road. I have to get my point across without ranting or being extreme. I like the challenge, because, in the end, that IS me. I believe both sides have valid points and our views are dynamic. If this is what works for John - that's really fantastic. Personally, I choose to be anonymous for exactly the opposite reasons John is under his own name. In every day life, I'm REALLY middle of the road. I'm mediocre. Normal. Rather boring. I'm too [_____] (afraid, chicken, silly, smart, cautious, P.C., socially aware, insincere - choose one) to say all the things that come out in my blog. For instance, I would never tell ANYONE that I had a very surreal dream about horse juice in real life. In my blog: there it is, hanging out all over the place. Being disgusting all on it's own. This makes me happy. I'm really really really me here. I'm stupid or smart or obnoxious or mean or kind without worrying who I will offend. I can easily say, "You don't like it? Fuck you then." because really, I don't know any of you. I only know what you write and one or two measly paragraphs a day is a far cry from the sum of your existence. The multi dimensional aspect of the interaction is missing. I don't have your tone of voice. I have no way of knowing what mannerisms you use when you talk. I don't know if you speak out of a gorgeous barbie body, or a not so plush "work in progress" shell. Without all of these things... I will never really know any of you. The bits I do get ... I appreciate. For me, the challenge is to let it out. Let out all those things that are usually too scared to come into the light. So, John likes his restraints, they force him to make is points in non-offensive and lucid ways. I like my lack of restraints... I'm as offensive as idiotic as I feel like. And some days, like today, I feel just a little bit like making sense. (mind you, it's all rubbish and tomorrow will be back to helldamnfart)

Steer clear of risky partners - From the urlLink Toronto Metro Daily Newspaper , Feb. 3/04 ---------------------------------------------- Many women who are or were involved with abusive men don’t realize that early warning signs were there from the beginning. This article – the first in a threepart series on dangerous partners – is intended to help women identify some key indicators of risky relationships and to assist them in making sounder choices before becoming seriously involved with someone who is physically and/or mentally abusive. One of the first red flags of an abusive man is his ability to become very serious too quickly. Usually he will claim to be totally enamoured with the woman because she is so much better than any of his exes. He will also talk very negatively about his past partners who apparently all cheated on him or deeply hurt him. Ironically, the intention is not to make the new woman feel special but to prepare her for what he expects of her in their relationship. On occasion an abuser will admit to having been physically violent with previous partners. This admission will entail a diminished version of the assault and an exaggerated account of how he was provoked to violence. There also will be no remorse for his actions. Instead, all blame will be shifted to the abused partner. Some men will even expect “brownie points” for being truthful about their past violence. That type of absurdity is no different than a murderer showing no remorse at a trial and expecting a full acquittal just because he tells the judge where the body is buried. Women should also be wary of men who in the early stages of a relationship discuss marriage and interest in having children. This information is of value to many abusive men because they are looking for women eager to get married and less likely to terminate their relationship if they act out. Another red flag of abusive men is their incessant need to be in constant contact with the woman. Love scares the shit out of me. There seems to be as many kinds of love as there are people. There's the hopeless love, dependant love, supportive love, platonic love, abused love, repressed love, joyous love, shallow love... love love love. I feel like it's an abused word. Kobe Bryant probably still tells his wife that he loves her, Lorena Bobbit loved her husband. L o v e has been dragged through the mud. I propose a tax on the word "love". $1000 every time you use it. Payable to charity. No wait, that would mean that rich people would get to love more than the rest of us. Oaky, 30 hours of community service - every time you say love. The word love comes out of your mouth and for the next four weekends you're in the soup kitchen, or volunteering at the library. Maybe people wouldn't abuse the word so much then. Teenage girls wouldn't shriek, "Justin Timerblake I LOVE YOU!" Guys wouldn't say, "Man, I love my new playstation." The word love would finally achieve more of the authority and dignity that it deserves. Then it would be right that it scares the shit out of me. Because then, I would know that when R.E. says he loves me, he means it. And I wouldn't have to be so scared, because I would be more secure in understanding what the hell I mean, when I tell him I love him. It's saying, "You're worth 30 hours of my time doing thankless tasks." Not very romantic, but sure as hell better than using the term to describe the yummy feeling you get when you taste your favorite pizza. "Dude, I LOVE extra cheese!" So people, I have a favour to ask: please don't use the word love so flippantly. Save it for those who really need it.

Frilly has offered to let me write a diatribe about the wonders of RSS here, and I'm happy to oblige. First off, what is RSS ? Depending on who you ask you get different answers. RSS is thought to be an acronym for R eally S imple S yndication, R ich S ite S ummary, or R DF S ite S ummary. I've always been partial to RSS meaning R eally S imple S yndication, and the urlLink specification I found seems to agree with me. No matter which acronym you take RSS to mean it all boils down to the same thing. Put quick and dirty, RSS is data presented in a simple format ( XML ), sometimes referred to as an RSS 'feed'. Thoroughly explaining what XML is and how it works are urlLink projects beyond the scope of this article ( urlLink here's a start if you want to learn ), but put simply XML is a pretty open-ended markup language that structures data. I usually find it easier to understand things when I can see them in action, so let's look at urlLink Matt's RSS Feed and seem some RSS doing its thing. What you see should look something along the lines of urlLink this . The tags (the red and blue items in my example picture) are the important part, the text will change every time urlLink Matt updates. If you have an understanding of HTML you can probably make out the syntax of the XML . All off the tags are enclosed in < and > tags, and are all pretty self explanatory. To see what RSS has to do with blogging, let's look at urlLink Matt's RSS Feed again. See all the text in between the tags? That's the 'blog' part of Matt's blog in there, minus all of the CSS styling and formatting. A blog without formatting seems pretty pointless. Someone went to all that time and effort to make their blog nice to look at (in most cases), and you reduce it to plain text? Not really much point to it until you introduce an urlLink Aggregator . A simple way to explain an RSS aggregator is as an RSS browser. You use urlLink Firefox to view web pages, you use urlLink NetNewsWire (or your aggregator of choice) to 'view' RSS feeds. Why use RSS and an aggregator instead of a browser? Speed is one good reason. Strip all that formatting and all those images out of the blog to get the RSS and you've greatly reduced the page size. Not a huge benefit if you have a broadband connection, but it can be a huge benefit to dial-up users (yes there are actually still urlLink a lot of dial-up users out there ). Once again I'll use urlLink Matt's site for an example. As of this writing Matt's page weighs in at about 55.8 kb , while his RSS feed weighs in at a rather svelte 4.8 kb . That means that the RSS feed can theoretically load over ten times faster ! While Matt's site isn't quite light ( urlLink WooWoo weighs in around 30 kb ) , it's not all that bloated either ( urlLink FUBAR weighs in around 128 kb ). An urlLink acceptable average for page weight is probably somewhere around 50-90 kb . Another way to save time using RSS feeds and aggregators deals pretty directly with blogging. How many times a day do you check your favorite bloggers to see if they have updated? Instead of loading up urlLink WooWoo fifteen times a day to see when Frilly has gotten around to updating your aggregator can do the work for you. Aggregators check the RSS feeds you subscribed to to see if there are any updates. When a site has been updated the aggregator displays some kind of notification to let you know there's new stuff to read. If you have broadband you can even leave the aggregator constantly running in the background throughout the day and have it check your favorite sites every fifteen minutes or so and be notified of updates throughout the day. RSS doesn't only benefit the audience. If you're a webmaster of a fairly popular web site, and people are constantly checking your page for updates they're also sucking up bandwidth every time they refresh the page. Take urlLink FUBAR as an example this time (because Justin seems to go over his bandwidth limit every other month). Instead of having all those people sucking down 128 kb every time some of them could be refreshing a 4 kb RSS feed. RSS can be faster, and save people money with just a little bit of work. Technology can be a great thing. Here are some questions I came up with. If you have more leave a comment and I'll try to answer them as best I can. What aggregator should I use? This all comes down to personal preference. Do you want it simple, or full featured? Are you willing to pay for it? Web based, or running on your computer? On my urlLink Mac at home I use the aforementioned urlLink NetNewsWire Lite for now. I'm waiting to see how urlLink Erik Barzeski's urlLink Pulp Fiction turns out. Erik has urlLink mentioned how PF will work and it seems to address a few problems I have with NetNewsWire. As far as Windows goes I haven't found a aggregator I really like yet. A lot of them require .NET support (?) which I can't install on my work computer (IT has me on all sorts of lock-down). If you have a favorite Windows aggregator leave a comment and I'll check it out, but the ones I've tried so far ( urlLink FeedReader and urlLink EffNews ) left me realizing how good NetNewsWire is. For now I'm using urlLink Bloglines , and it's good enough for now. I only have to use Windows at work, so I'm not planning on paying for anything. What about urlLink Atom ? Is it better than RSS ? The urlLink Atom versus RSS argument is a bit of a hot issue in geek-land right now. You can urlLink Google the issue and get a good amount to read. Right now I honestly don't know enough about the 'benefits' of Atom to argue if it's better or not. RSS was there first and until urlLink Blogger urlLink jumped on the Atom bandwagon it looked like Atom was fighting an losing battle, now it seems like it's a closer fight. Your best bet is probably to find an aggregator that supports both and ride it out.

Funny, seems like they now have a name for what it's like to be ME. No, wait, this could be any kid. It could be anyone at all who is reasonably intelligent and a little Obsessive Compulsive. urlLink Asperger Syndrome Individuals with AS can exhibit a variety of characteristics and the disorder can range from mild to severe. Persons with AS show marked deficiencies in social skills, have difficulties with transitions or changes and prefer sameness. They often have obsessive routines and may be preoccupied with a particular subject of interest. They have a great deal of difficulty reading nonverbal cues (body language) and very often the individual with AS has difficulty determining proper body space. Often overly sensitive to sounds, tastes, smells, and sights, the person with AS may prefer soft clothing, certain foods, and be bothered by sounds or lights no one else seems to hear or see. It's important to remember that the person with AS perceives the world very differently. Therefore, many behaviors that seem odd or unusual are due to those neurological differences and not the result of intentional rudeness or bad behavior, and most certainly not the result of "improper parenting". I think I could describe most of my blogging links as great candidates for this "syndrome" Perhaps now that we know we have a "condition" we can all get disability cheques from our respective governments.

This summer I am going to conquer the "perfect" blog entry. You know those entries that are intelligent and introspective without being self-centred? Those entries that have a clear point and actually use facts to back up their opinions. Yeah, those are the entries I want to write. The problem is that I don't think that I have the necessary motivation to start writing like that. I read people like the urlLink Stumbling Tongue and I'm already completely intimidated. I've always liked writing but I'm obviously not up to the standards of many of more popular bloggers. That leaves me with the horrible specter of mediocrity. If that's how it's going to be: just okay, then someone please cut the tendons in my fingers so that I cant't type any more. Truly excellent writers make me wonder. How much effort goes into every entry? Are there hours of agonizing, checking the flow of ideas, making sure of facts and editing down to the last punctuation mark? Are there consultations with friends and co-workers about how a certain word works in a sentence? I doubt it. The best entries read smoothly, naturally. They scan effortlessly and you can follow the idea from the begining to the end of each sentence. It's like Venus coming out of the sea fully formed. It just is. I suppose if I put a lot more time and effort into it, I could become a better writer... but really, I just want to have a natural talent. The things I like the best are the things that I don't have to work for. I want my talent to be recognized, not my hard work. I suppose I have that completely backwards, but considering that this whole entry is a big waste of your time, you'll just have to forgive me for these precious moments of your life that you will never have back.

It's the documentary about the history and the impact of corporations on a global scale. Infinitely informative. Pfizer, the company famous for many pharmaceuticals used by people the world over, demonstrated how they "give back" to the human race. The Vice President took us on a tour of a neighbourhood that had previously been dangerous. Although, the only testament we have to the danger of said community is that the VP was "almost" mugged there, once. I don't know what an "almost" mugging is... it must be when that thuggish, big, black fella on the stairs cuts his eyes at you. The community's improvements included Pfizer subsidized housing, and two improvements to the subway station: new barriers that prevented gate jumping and an emergency intercom system. I like that this is how Pfizer chooses to make this community so much safer. Obviously the main threats you have to worry about are those hooligans who will jump the gate instead of paying the $2 (or however much the subway costs there). The intercom is a laudable imporvement, although, if there was acutally someone on the other end to respond, it would be much more effective. The subsidized housing makes me wary. Firstly, I only saw three townhouses that had been spruced up. Second of all, the people who live there are now "owned" by Pfizer. There is no way that the housing is given pro bono. There is leverage here. What Pfizer partners or subsidies benefited from this renovation? Are the appliances General Electric? Did a large corporation get the construction contract, rather than a local builder? Is the local corner store now required to sell Rolaids© (Pfizer) instead of Tums© (GlaxoSmithKline) out of "gratitude" to Pfizer for fixing them up so well? Has crime in this area really decreased? The two ladies on the street that the VP waylaid seemed to be utterly uninformed as to the improvements, as well as the initial problems. Were the residents of this area given the choice as to the form that these improvements would take? Did they decide that an important factor in neighbourhood safety is having daunting subway gates that resemble doors on jail cells? Why was the VP calling these folks neighbours? Why? Because the office isn't far off. And that, my friends is why this community can count themselves so "lucky". Although the heart is in the right place, the affaire is mismanaged in classic form. Perhaps I misspeak. Perhaps the heart isn't there at all. Maybe this isn't an exercise in altruism, but rather a small cog in Pfizer's PR campaign. What they would call a "win/win" situation. At least they're trying, sort of. Go see "The Corporation." Make informed political decisions.

I went to one of the nicer spa/salons in my hometown last weekend and had a manicure. While I was sitting at the table, the girl sloughing gritty scrub all over my hands, I realized that the modern day spa is the equivalent to the ancient harem. The women chatter and gossip, the men are only present in the conversation and we spend the whole time beautifying ourselves, screened off from the real world. I can only imagine what kind of papmered hell it must have been to be a wife or concubine to a man with many others like me. The atmosphere at the spa made me nervous... that many women together, tongues all lashing, no restrictions due to inappropriate audiences. The romantic picture of the exotic woman, draped on her divan while attendants hover with treats was foremost in my mind. It's like there was an undercurrent of tension running through the place. The chatter was pleasant, civil, charming but as a woman you realize that under all that there is a significant amount of buried emotion, a subtext that is never referenced, words that are never said but exist between the women none the less. It's a aura of secrets kept, promises broken and thinly veiled barbarism. All of the treatments are designed to be relaxing, sensual and comforting. Instead the atmosphere full of switch blades and concealed fangs made me extremely happy to leave. My hands are soft, my nails are beautiful and I won't ever go back again. I'd rather fill a tub at home and spend an hour to myself, scrubbing and moisturizing without the worry of constant scrutiny.

Monday we are having a federal election. In Canada (for those of you who don't know) there are 5 major parties. 1. The Liberals - equivalent to U.S. democrats, but a little bit more leftward leaning. They've been rocked by scandals over the past few months and the general public is leery of them. They SHOULD win the election. They are the party that most reflects what "Canada" is. 2. The Conservatives (Republicans): have mentioned privatizing health care, only to back off. Want to give tax breaks and buy Canada three Air Craft Carriers. Against abortion rights. Are idiots. Will make us the fifty first state (sorry, but if I wanted to live in the US, I would). 3. New Democratic Party (NDP): as far left as Canada goes. This is our socialist choice. Pro-welfare, pro-affordable housing for the poor, pro-federal day care, pro-strong environmental conservation. A lot of lovely ideas but leaves me wondering whether it will be me and many other middle income families who would be paying for these services. 4. Partie Quebecois: a seperatist French movement, popular only in Quebec and some french-speaking parts of Manitoba. Want to make themselves into a new country. Other wise they are willing to partner up with whoever loses the election to make life hell for the winners. 5. The Green Party: on first glimpse, a good choice. Not many people are aware that other than their radical environmental stand, they are extremely conservative. Against immigration, against women's rights - this party could set us back about 50 years. I'm going to vote Liberal - even though they've been in power for 8 years already. They seem best equipped to deal with the upcoming four years. Even though they've wasted a lot of the taxpayer's money, I'd rather it was them, than Stephen Harper and the Conservatives taking away my choice as a woman, and giving tax breaks to big corporations who are raping our earth.

Help. I'm under attack from the happy monster. No really, please. help. me. I can't take it. Okay, I can. Life is pretty sweet right now. It's not perfect - but then I never expect it to be. It's just as good as it can be. I've got a good job, a cute apartment, a loving pudding (cat), a great family, a cheque from Mum in the mail, sunshine/summer, a date next week that will be luscious, the office to myself, a blossoming blog (thanks for the motivation Bill), 16 bottles of wine, a busy social life and a rewarding television schedule (none at all!). The only thing that could possibly make this better is having someone to share my perma-smile with. I don't believe in that "you complete me" crap. Love and relationships are things that you should only enter as a whole person. It's hard enough keeping yourself together, but when you are partially responsible for someone else's happiness, you had better know what you're about. I don't want someone to complete me, and I don't want to complete someone else. I'm a complete puzzle, no pieces missing. The key to love is not just LOVE itself, but entering into it with the right attitude. So often people seem to lose themselves in their partner. You can no longer distinguish between Joe and Susie. They turn into Joe'nSusie. No matter how similar people are, there should always be a sense of individuality. This is the connection of two people, not a synthesis into one person. Also, if you're heartbroken, lost, depressed, or otherwise "unwhole" - you have no right to tell someone you love them. Until you figure out if you really LOVE them, or whether you just love that they fill a hole in your life, keep your mouth shut. One last thing: don't ever say, "I didn't do anything wrong, I don't owe you an apology. I have my pride." If you've upset someone you love, you should care enough to at least apologize for hurting them. They should do the same for you.
