I suppose I could write a post about almost anything. The picture above my desk. The dream about being in jail. How busy I am. How different the subway is at night, compared to rush hour. The question is, what do I want to write about that you, my fair reader, would be interested in? Surely the painting above my desk is lovely... but a picture would solve the problem of how to describe it. Surley my dream about being locked in jail was strange - but most dreams are. How about the subway? People walk slower at night, there's more couples and the trains are more empty. There's less of a rushed feeling and more a relaxed, tired feeling. I went north for two extra stops because I wasn't paying attention and found the most beautiful station. The walls were covered in tiny mosaic tiles with depictions of huge leaves and blooming flowers. It must date back to the 50's or 60's as nowadays things are all clean, clear and colourless. The newest station in Toronto has a mosaic of it's own, but the colours are muted and it resembles a paint by numbers creation. In fact, it's a photograph that has been pixelated and then transfered to the wall, each tile representing a pixel. I prefer the freeform flowers and plants. The couples on the subway in the morning are all dressed in suits and they talk amongst themselves very seriously. The couples in the evening sit on each other's laps and giggle a lot more. There are no kids or teenagers in the morning. At night, you can listen to about 12 different songs blasting from headphones while the kids yell at each other over the squeal of the metal wheels. There are a lot more shopping bags, small pets and children at night. There are a lot more brief cases, newspapers and small purses in the morning. There's always spilled coffee on the floor.

Don't start thinking that she's a wild party animal who drives too fast - it's the opposite. She never, ever seems to be just plain old happy and healthy. She would have been perfect in the 1800's. A delicate woman, always fainting at the sign of any excitement. I don't know if she's just susceptible to viruses and bacteria, or if she, as an organism, is not healthy. Maybe she's just incredibly accident prone. Some cases to illustrate my point: We joined the gym. She started working out in old running shoes. We ran for maybe, 5 minutes a day, at first. Withing two weeks she had a stress fracture in her foot. The next month she waded around with a strap on cast. She tripped on the street last week and scrapped up her ankle and bruised her hip. She spent the next week visitng chiropractors because she felt nauseaus every time she sat up. She was so upset that she also screwed up her stomach and almost had to go to the hospital. Her boyfriend stepped on her foot and her toe nail fell off. She got elbowed by mistake at the bar and spent the rest of the night bent over in agony. We had to leave within half an hour. She wore uncomfortable shoes to the bar one night and spent the next three days in slippers because of the agony of her feet. She cannot drink brown pop, but she can drink any colourless pop. She cannot eat salad - it gives her "gall" attacks. Going outside at all, activates her asthma. Unsing kleenex when she's got a cold makes her sneeze more. She is allergic to it. We walked for half an hour over the May long weekend and her hip joint hurt her for the rest of the day. Orange juice and Tomatoes give her hives She is afraid of driving, of elevators and escalators, of the subway and of homeless people. She will not go outside without all of her makeup on. What the hell is going on with this girl? I don't want to think the worst of her, but some of this has to be in her head. The pain might be real, but there has to be some subconcious need for attention, or pampering that makes her react so badly to so many things. I don't think that I can ever name a time when she was just "normal". Mind you, her family is riddled with health problems and they are all constantly self medicating. Maybe normal to her is having something wrong . Either way, it made for three very long days with her - while it rained outside. Cooking for her is a nightmare - no garlic, no onions, no vegetables with seeds in them, no orange juice, distilled water only, no spices... I love her to death. She is my support system and she is always there for me when it counts. We usually have an effortless friendship, finding each other in the same frame of mind most of the time. Last weekend I couldn't wait to get rid of her. Her boyfriend came to pick her up from my house and I was SO happy to let him take her home to deal with all the issues. We've been friends for over three years now, and in that time, none of her neuroses have improved. I find myself wondering if they ever will. I find myself, for the first time, in a crisis regarding our friendship. Can I be best friends with someone who seems not to grow? Who has no sense of adventure? Who never wants to try new things? Is it enough that we care about each other? How do I avoid growing out of this friendship? I don't want to. I do care about her, a lot, but I'm afriad that my frustration will show through - and consequently hurt her. She is so fragile...

I get back from buying some office supplies and R.E. accosts me. "I want to talk to you." Me: "Okay" Him: "Now!" Me: "Okay, already." At which point we wander down the corridor whispering heatedly about how he hasn't been talking to me and I think it would be best if he was at least civil. 10 minutes later he's still telling me that he has to get over loving me and that it's hard for him etc. etc. I tell him that we would not have worked out anyway, so there is no point in mooning over me. I say that we are too different, he, too squirrely, me too irresponsible and lackadaisical (sp?). Add to that his criticisms and it would have crashed and burned, either way you look at it. He says he never meant to criticize me, he said "these things out of love", he was trying to take care of me. I tell him that that's alright, for children, but I'm 25 and can take care of myself. If I don't take care of myself, that's my choice too. I tell him that I'm convinced that we wouldn't be good together and I think that he's got himself convinced otherwise. Him: "Don't tell me that I'm falling in love like an idiot." Meaning that he's blind to the reality of the situation. I look at him. All of his friends told him NOT to marry his ex-wife, but he did. She came to Canada and started sleeping with another man, while she was living with him. This went on for six months. If that marriage wasn't a blind/bad choice, then I don't know what is. Still he tells me that he was only half a man when we were together... he knows that he is someone different but he has to "jump over" his problems before he can be in a relationship. I counter, "then why the hell did you start anything with me?!" On and on, in whispers, in the hall. Eventually he says, "I do not have any problem with you, that is the point here." Me:"Okay, fine, do what you have to do." Thank god we're not together - this is ridiculous. I don't know what the hell he's mooning over, although it's easy for me to say because I'm the one who had no problem moving on, and now I'm very happy with the Golden Boy. I don't know what it's like to be the one left behind, but perhaps I should try and be more empathetic towards R.E. and not give him such a hard time.

The Golden Boy recently said that he would like to have a shirt with French Cuffs. You know, the kind of dress shirt that requires beautiful manly cuff links. Cherie, I beg to differ. It is not itsy bitsy or teeny weeny, it is tailored and stylish and each cuff has a pair of cuff link type holes, done up with two buttons tied together. In a foolish attempt to preserve the pristine condition of my beautiful, new, white blouse, I rolled up my sleeve at lunch today. This involved undoing the lovely cuff-link type cuffs. It is time to go home and I would like to look as little like the sectretly slobby, messy person that I really am. I want to do up my cuffs again. Subsequently, I have spent that past 20 minutes fiddling, nay, flailing in a "where's those padded walls that are so dear?" sort of manner while I try and slot a button through two layers of material at a 180° to the hand that must do the slotting. Or slutting, however you'd like to say it. It is time to go home and I would like to look as little like the sectretly slobby, messy person that I really am. I want to do up my cuffs again. Either way, it is now t-minus 6 mintues until home time and I am still unable to do up my own clothing. Does this mean that I must ask Pilsbury, with the horrible laugh track and the sausage fingers, to aid me in dressing myself? Does this mean that I will be denied boarding of the street car while the passengers stare on in shock at my deshabille? Unless of course, the Golden boy is there to help me do them up again. A situation which he might take advantage of by buttoning my wrists together and then UN-buttoning every other button he can find. I suppose I wouldn't be totally against that. As long as we weren't at work with everyone looking on. As it is... everyone is now looking on while my arms seem to have taken on mystical bendy powers and my wrists writhe in heretofore unmentionable manners. I think I've got the sleeves pulled so far down that my bra straps are showing. I still can't get the damned things done up. At least I don't have urlLink cabbage in my bra.

First of all I should tell you I was only a sorority girl for a week. After that, you have to pay money. Oh, and they have to want you. Which they didn't. I didn't mind. During my first week of University - before classes - also known as FROSH week, I "rushed" - that is, tried out for - two of the sororities available on campus. I went to the initial meeting for the first one (Sorority GD) where they introduce themselves, talk about the sorority, tell you what it's like to be involved etc. Now DG girls have a sorority house, where lots of DGs live. In this house there were to be no: 1. Drinking 2. Overnight guests 3. Drops in grades 4. Illegal substances This was the first and only meeting I went to for Sorority DG. I'm not going to pay $600 a term so that I cannot do things. It's just not going to happen. I went to the initial meeting for the second one (Sorority AO) and they did allow drinking and boys and well, not so much the illegal substances, but I was willing to overlook that. Evidently, AO would serve my purposes. I was only a sorority girl for one week, but in that time I used every moment to my social advantage. I suppose I should let it be known that it was not ever my intention to join either of these sororities. My primary motivation for "rushing" was to meet Frat Boys. You see, sorority sisters were almost always invited to Frat events, esspecially during rush. I went to two wine and cheeses, two keggers, and a mixer. My best friend and I both met frat boys and both short lived relationships (if you could call them that) ended badly. But - for that first week on I knew not only the Frosh, but 2nd and 3rd years, guys and girls. I never looked back.

Dear urlLink Matt , I have the feeling that you are one of those nice guys, who, right up to this very moment, has been unlucky in love. From some of the comments you've made, you've nudged me in the direction of a certain opinion. Now, this opinion may be completely wrong, and if that is the case, I apologize. I am going to write you this open letter because I have come across so many nice men, who seem to be forever lost in unrequited love. I will also be speaking on the behalf of women in general, which is taking a liberty that I hope women the world over will forgive me for. Matt, (and all nice men out there) please understand me. WOMEN LOVE NICE MEN. We really do. What we cannot cope with is men who, after two weeks, are ready to lay down their lives for us. We cannot deal with the sappy look you get in your eyes, if it's on the first date. It's really sweet that you like us that much, but it makes us worry. Yes, be nice, but also show your individuality. Show us that you have opinions of your own and will contradict us if you don't agree. If a girl treats you badly, for God's sake: GET ANGRY with her. Yes, women in general need to be treated gently, but the minute she becomes self-serving and ceases to give you the same amount of consideration you are giving her - then my friend, it is time to grow a spine and tell her that it's not okay with you. Until you are capable of confronting these women you care for, you will find yourself locked in a battle that you cannot win. Don't make excuses for us. Don't smile and say, "It's okay, you tore my heart out, but I'll be fine." Playing the martyr will only let you in for pity... not the respect that you want. Women find men who are confident sexy. Know who you are, what you will accept (or not) and be willing to speak up if she crosses your boundaries. DO NOT let her walk on you. Love her, by all means, but don't love her so much that you put yourself last. Women can sense this in a man and until you shape up, they will continue to manipulate/use/deceive you. Matt, I love your kindness, your goodwill, your sense of romance. I would love to hear that you are happy with some charming girl who loves you to bits. Just don't let your heart melt your spine. There is such a thing as TOO nice. All the best in love and life, Frilly

That's it. He's (the Golden Boy) used the "L" word. We've only been dating for three weeks. Admittedly, we already knew each other but not in the context of a relationship. How can he be so ready to use such a powerful word? Love, to me, is about permanence... not the bliss you feel during the first few weeks of a relationship. The bliss is a sneaky emotion, tricking people into thinking that everything will be alright. It's when the bliss receedes and I look at my partner objectively, and I still feel the same way, THEN I feel like I can use the word LOVE.I think I tried to explain this to him at the time, but didn't do a very good job. On the other hand, the happiness I feel when we're together, sipping wine on a patio, snuggled on the couch, walking down the street... it demands to be expressed. I "love" what I'm feeling, I "love" how he makes me feel. It makes me want to talk about love, certainly. As a disclaimer, I CAN see myself loving him, I adore him already but just need more time to cement my emotions. "...it's not yet all of him I love. It's what we're going through." The fact that he's said, "love" now adds pressure to this situation. He's not intending it that way, but now that I know he loves me, I have to realize that there may be a "broken heart" involved if something goes wrong. I would just like to think that we are caught up in something beautiful, but still keeping our rational minds. The fact that he's willing to be irrational and emotional makes me a wee bit nervous. Maybe I'm just being too uptight. Maybe I should choose the romantic path and follow him and my heart to happy oblivion. The problem is that I've chosen the oblivion before and it doesn't seem to turn out too well. I don't think it's ever safe to let myself get too caught up in things. I need the reassurance of clear, COLD thinking. I can't help but feel that a relationship founded on common sense stands more chance than the romatic swirl of a love affaire. There's always the chance that the love affaire will work out to something long term and this is what I'm going to hope for. I'm going to hope that I can follow him down the path of bliss and emotion and come out the other side even happier than I thought possible. God help me. Update. Alright. I love him. Hopelessly, giddily in love. Absolutely madly happy. Sickeningly smitten.

My best friend (let's call her Bunny) recently sent an email to a girl (let's call her Biatch) who she had been close to a few years ago. The frienship had been dying and it was difficult for Bunny because Biatch was demanding and she kept bringing up topics that she knew were painful to Bunny. She would call Bunny almost every day and then demand to know why Bunny didn't call her back immediately. Bunny's email was pretty straight forward. She told her that she cares about Biatch, but that the friendship was not ever going to be as close as it was a few years ago. She was having problems with the relationship and thought that it would be better to end it, for many reasons. This is what she gets in return: Bunny, Well what can I say?I am not at all mad, actually relieved... But to be honest I feel it is a good thing that you and I are no longer friends because I spent so much time worrying about how you were all the time when you were going through all kinds of crap, I worried and thought about you all the time....and neglected myself and my life in the process. With my life the way it is now...I know that there is no way I would be able to do any thinking about you seeing as I have a lot of things going on in my life as well...and I have realized who my real friends are....and they have been there for me...like I was for you. You were a drain on me mentally and I was ok with that... but now I see that I kinda wasted my time...trying to build a life long friendship, silly me! I put a lot into our friendship and for you to push it away due to the fact that S. is my brother, well to me seems petty. I see we are in two different stages in life. I am mature and stable...where as you seem to still be lost in the ways of life and are acting like a child. Maybe when you grow up you will realize the mistakes you have made, it will be too late for us, but maybe people you meet later will be able to stand the drama of being your friend. Someone needs to smack some sence into you. I think you need to take some time and look in the mirror and ask yourself "WHAT THE HELL IS WRONG WITH ME??" Because you are going be asked that a lot by other people in your life if you keep this teenage logic, it is best to be prepared and have an answer for them. Life is short and I am not about to waist my time with someone who can not be mature about anything in life. Good luck to you in life because you are going to need it. But I think your Boyfriend is going to need it a bit more. Biatch p.s Reality is going to creep up on you and you are not going to be prepared. Time to open your eyes. My best friend wants to write this Biatch a reply but I've been trying to tell her that someone who writes an email like that does not deserve a response. What chance does she have of talking any sense to this girl? Obviously Biatch is hurt more than she says, and she's taking that pain out on Bunny. She's using every weapon available to her, guilt, personal attacks, insults... Women can be so very AWFUL.

He returns an email (paraphrased here): ME: "What does this mean? You hope that we can be together in the future? I still have to say that I don't think that we would work out." R.E.: No, from the beginning I warned you that I wasn't right for you. I knew that we could never be together. I want you only as a friend. It looks like you are confused. I'm not a hypocrite, I wouldn't want you to jeopardize your relationship. You will not heal until you have a support system of friends. Help me find my friends. ARGH!!! In the begining, once, he did say, "I think I'm not the right guy for you." and I got upset and asked him why but his only response was, "Because." Perhaps this is what he's referring to. I'm even more ticked now than I was before because I feel like he's trying to make a fool of me. He's trying to make it sound like I'm so wrapped up in myself, and convinced that he still wants me. I can't help it if that is what I thought. The things he was saying were certainly enough to make anyone believe that's what he meant. If it isn't - it's another case of crossed-wires for us, and yet another reason why our relationship was so DAMN difficult. My response will be along the lines of this: sorry if I misunderstood you, but that is why I told you I was confused and I needed you to clear up the situation for me. That being said... let's just get on with our lives. Why did this have to be such a huge issue? If all he really wanted to say was that he'd hoped I would have come to him in person and that he'd appreciate it if I didn't blab about this, then it could have been said in a much less emotionally loaded email. DRAMA!

I also told him that as a woman, I get my emotional support from my friends and therefore I would certainly be talking about this situation with my best friend, at the least.
